overview: This subject investigates connections between science and art in animation, exploring data visualisation and motion graphics, designing and creating animation for gallery and museum contexts.
Students will research experimental animation methods and explore possible future techniques of animation.
Students will also explore textures, structures and materials of animation and developing their folios of production assets related to this study.
intended learning outcomes: research experimental animation methods and concepts;
apply experimental production techniques to express screen-based ideas;
create and organise animation production assets for an experimental production;
design an animation to communicate complex concepts;
apply the technical requirements for animation in a museum and gallery;
evaluate and apply feedback to build on experimental animation productions.

assessments.description: Three in-class exercises with accompanying 3-minute oral presentations. 20 hours (of work required)
Production development folio. 20 hours (of work required)

Hurdle requirement:. Students must submit all elements of assessment to be eligible for a pass in this subject. For the purposes of meeting this hurdle requirement, each submitted assessment must be complete and constitute a genuine attempt to address the requirements of the task. Submitting only part of an assessment (e.g. only the title page) or an assessment on an irrelevant topic will not meet this hurdle requirement.
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 75% of all scheduled classes.

Semester 2.Contact hours: 36 hours, comprising one 3-hour workshop per week
